questions.text: All are used in the management of pericarditis EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anticoagulants Anticoagulants should be avoided because their use could cause bleeding into the pericardial cavity and tamponade.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Bed rest and anti-inflammatory treatment with aspirin (2–4 g/d), with NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen (600–800 mg tid) or indomethacin (25–50 mg tid), and should be administered along with gastric protection. Option: B: Glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone 1 mg/kg per day) usually suppress the clinical manifestations of acute pericarditis in patients who have failed therapy with or do not tolerate NSAIDs and colchicine. Option: D: Colchicine enhances the response to NSAIDs and also aids in reducing the risk of recurrent pericarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included as the principal feature of cardiac tamponade (Beck’s triad)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kussmaul’s sign Kussmaul’s sign is seen in constrictive pericarditis, Restrictive cardiomyopathy, and RVMI. The three principal features of tamponade (Beck’s triad) are hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Soft or absent heart sounds. Option: C: Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent. Option: D: The limitations to ventricular filling are responsible for reductions of cardiac output and arterial pressure.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and peripheral edema. A chest radiograph lateral view is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic constrictive pericarditis The x-ray shows heavy pericardial calcification as in Chronic constrictive pericarditis which is supported by clinical features. The chest roentgenogram shows a normal or slightly enlarged heart. Pericardial calcification is most common in tuberculous pericarditis. Pericardial calcification may, however, occur in the absence of constriction, and constriction may occur without calcification.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Calcification is less common. Option: C: Enlarged heart shadow without calcification. Option: D: Normal lung field.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male was brought to the clinic with complaints of weakness, restlessness, and chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. On auscultation, heart sounds are muffled and his neck veins are observed to be distended. The most typical finding in the JVP of this patient would be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Absent y decent Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds and raised JVP are characteristic features of Cardiac Tamponade and are referred to together as Beck's triad. There is the absence of y wave of JVP in Cardiac Tamponade

questions.text: A young motorist sustained injuries in a major road traffic accident. He was found to have fractures of the left femur and left humerus. He also had multiple rib fractures on the anterior aspect. On examination, BP was 80/60 mmHg and HR was 140/min. The patient was agitated, restless, and tachypneic. Jugular veins were distended. Air entry was adequate in both lung fields. Heart sounds were barely audible. Femoral pulses were weakly palpable and distally no pulse could be felt. On a priority basis, what should be the immediate intervention?

options.label: D
options.text: Fixation of left femur and repair of the femoral artery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urgent pericardial tap The presence of hypotension, distended neck veins, and absent heart sounds is suggestive of Cardiac tamponade. An urgent pericardial tap needs to be done to relieve tension in the heart

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Blood transfusion is indicated in hypotension caused due to massive blood loss. In this case, hypotension is due to Cardiac tamponade. Option C : ICD placement is done in hemothorax or pneumothorax Option D : Fixation of femur fracture is not the first priority here.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She was short of breath and her spo2 revealed 90%. Her ECG is given below. Which of the following is Incorrect in relation to this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: A prominent x descent but an absent y descent is seen on JVP

options.label: B
options.text: A important clue to the diagnosis of this condition is a greater than 10 mm Hg decline in systolic arterial pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Next best investigation in this case in echocardiography

options.label: D
options.text: Pericardial knock can be heard on cardiac auscultation

questions.correct_answer: D. Pericardial knock can be heard on cardiac auscultation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pericardial knock can be heard on cardiac auscultation This patient is having cardiac tamponade. His ECG reveals 1. sinus tachycardia,2. low QRS voltage and 3. electric alternans (best seen in leads V3 and V4, in this case). This triad is highly specific for pericardial effusion, usually with tamponade physiology, but of limited sensitivity. Pericardial knock is heard in constrictive pericarditis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Jugular venous distension with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent is seen in cardiac tamponade. Option B: The important clue to the presence of cardiac tamponade consists of a greater than normal (10 mm Hg) inspiratory decline in systolic arterial pressure. Option C: Because immediate treatment may be life-saving, prompt establishment of diagnosis by echocardiography should be undertaken.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery bypass graft surgery 1 year ago presents with fatigue, dyspnea, and progressive lower extremity edema. Examination reveals a blood pressure of 120/70 mm Hg and a pulse of 77 beats per minute. The lungs are clear. The heart is quiet, with normal first and second heart sounds and no murmurs. The jugular venous pressure ( JVP) is elevated at mid-neck (approximately 20 cm water). There is an increase in the JVP with inspiration with rapid descent. What does this combination of findings strongly suggest?

options.label: A
options.text: Heart failure due to biventricular dysfunction

options.label: D
options.text: Failure of the bypass grafts and recurrent coronary artery disease

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Constrictive pericarditis Constrictive pericarditis is a relatively infrequent complication of open heart surgery, yet cardiac surgery is now the number one cause of constrictive pericarditis causing heart failure. Heart failure often begins slowly, with symptoms of dyspnea, peripheral edema, and signs of elevated neck veins and the Kussmaul sign—elevation of JVP with inspiration. Another finding often reported on the JVP is rapid descent . Options A, B, and D are not the correct option
